Award.AwardTitle: Unraveling the propagation and repercussions of localized perturbations within tissues

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this proposal is to uncover how important signals travel between cells in epithelial tissues that form the lining of most animal organs. This communication is essential for maintaining healthy tissues, wound healing, and responding to infection and cancer. The project will employ a multidisciplinary combination of experimental and modeling approaches, and will provide opportunities for education, training, and public engagement. These broader impact activities include; 1) developing a course that would allow students to study multi-cellular interactions, 2) provide interdisciplinary training for the next generation of scientists, 3) allow for undergraduate internships for summer research experience, 4) create web-modules on the topic for citizen scientists, and 5) develop museum exhibits related to synthetic biology and cell-to-cell communication.

This project aims to gain quantitative insight into how localized changes in a tissue propagate and impact tissue signaling and physiology. In particular, using an integrated experimental and computational approach, we will study how cAMP/PKA, Ca2+ and ERK signaling is coordinated within an individual epithelial cell, and how signals emanating from these pathway propagate from one cell to others in a tissue. Optogenetic tools will be developed to apply spatially and temporally precise perturbations to these pathways in designated single cells within a tissue, and then measure the resulting signaling and transcriptional activities in the sender cells where perturbations are initiated as well as receiver cells that sense the propagated perturbation. Emergent phenotypic repercussions of such perturbations, such as cellular mobility, will be assessed. To organize and interpret the data, generalize findings, and design maximally informed experiments, mathematical models that uniquely consider the tissue geometry and impact of spatial dimensions and heterogeneity on interactions within cell groups will be constructed. This multidisciplinary approach will allow for the generation of a quantitative understanding of the fundamental principles of collaboration in cell communities and the modalities by which local perturbations propagate and impact tissue physiology.

This project is funded by the Systems and Synthetic Biology Program in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Developmental processes are organized at the level of cell communities. Cancer progression is also a disease process best described as a breakdown in organization of cell communities. In fact, cancer pathologists rely on the structural organization of groups of cells in histology sections to assess prognosis and prescribe course of treatment. However, most molecular biologists continue to rely on the properties and regulatory states of single cells when describing tumors. This work is intended to develop a quantitative framework to understand signaling relationships between cells and their breakdown in disease, to help bridge the gap between these two approaches and unravel intricacies of cancer and other complex diseases of tissues.

To date, we have lacked understanding of the quantitative principles of cell-cell communication protocols and ensuing collective behaviors of cell communities. More poignantly, we have little insights into how localized changes in a tissue, or perturbations to some cells but not others, propagate to neighboring cells and impact tissue physiology. We sought to tackle this challenge in a meaningful setting focusing the cAMP pathway, a central cellular information processing hub. We therefore engineered cells to contain a light activated adenylyl cyclase, an enzyme that can produce cAMP inside cells. We mixed these “sender” cells with “receiver” cells that don’t contain the light-activated enzyme, and studied how the cAMP signals propagated across the cell monolayers as we stimulate the “sender” cells with light.  Observations of the dynamics of “sender” and “receiver” cells allowed us to understand various aspects of their communication through gap junctions, molecules that are akin to communication channels that neighboring cells share. We discovered that these communication channels are dynamically regulated by the signals that they are trying to convey, and that their dynamics are critical for the quantitative patterns of inter-cellular information transfer.

In addition to the biological insights generated, we developed in this project computational models that allowed us to simulate different scenarios of cell-cell communication in order to understand the dynamical signaling patterns that we observed. In addition, facilitate the engineering of the cell-lines in this study, we developed a new and general cellular engineering platform, now gaining wide used in the scientific community.  This project, which is positioned at the intersection of cell biology, computational modeling, and cell engineering allowed us to introduce all of these aspects to a broad audience of aspiring scientists. Through the education and outreach components of our project, we fostered students from local bay area high school students as well as undergraduates from various colleges and universities to participate in biological discovery and cellular engineering aspects of this project.  These experiences helped shape their academic and career goals with some choosing to continue on a scientific or cellular engineering path in academia or industry.
